title-group.article-title: Blood support in coronary bypass surgery

body.p: We congratulate the authors for the study, “The impact of off-pump coronary artery bypass surgery on postoperative renal function.”1 They mentioned that off-pump coronary bypass surgery is related to less postoperative renal failure compared to on-pump surgery. The study suggests that clinical and demographıc data of on-pump and off-pump groups are similar, but there is no information about the comparison of perioperative blood support. Many studies showed that the probability of postoperative renal dysfunction increases with the use of blood in cardiac surgery2-5. In a study by Whitson et al.5, it was found that using blood products increased the incidence of acute renal failure. The ratio of acute renal failure in the group that did not receive any blood products was 1.8% whereas it was calculated at 8% in the group of blood product recipients, which was statistically significant. There are some other studies demonstrating that an increment in the amount of blood products used causes a rise in the development of postoperative renal failure. Godet et al.4 investigated risk factors for acute renal failure among patients undergoing thoracic and thoracoabdominal aortic surgery. According to the results of this study, an average of seven units of packed red blood cells was used in the group which was free of acute renal failure whereas 11 units were used in the group which developed it. This difference was statistically significant. A mean of 2.1 L of fresh frozen plasma (FFP) was used in the group which was free from acute renal failure whereas, in those where it developed, 2.9 L of FFP were used. This difference was statistically significant as well. As a result, we believe that perioperative blood support should be mentioned to the claim that off-pump coronary surgery is related to less postoperative renal failure.
